topic_seeds.description: Feeling isolated and disconnected from others
Worrying excessively about health symptoms (complex, layered situation)
Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines
Experiencing panic attacks or intense anxiety episodes

exchanges.user:
Been meaning to reach out. Work has been absolutely brutal this past week. We had this deadline pushed up by two weeks and nobody told me until Monday morning. I was already stretched thin on the current project, so now I'm juggling three different things with no clear priority. My manager keeps saying "just do your best" which is basically code for "figure it out yourself."

The thing that's getting to me is I can't sleep properly. I'll lie awake at 2am running through all the ways this could go wrong. What if I miss something critical? What if the client finds bugs in production? Then it spirals from there.

Also been feeling pretty isolated lately. Haven't seen my friends in like a month. They keep inviting me out but I keep declining because I'm either working or just exhausted. Part of me knows that's probably making things worse, but I don't have the energy to explain to anyone what's actually going on. It's easier to just say I'm busy.

Anyway, wanted to check in and see if you had any thoughts on the sleep thing specifically. That's what's really killing me right now.
exchanges.assistant:
**The sleep spiral:** That 2am loop you described—where your mind runs through everything that could go wrong—makes complete sense when you're already stretched thin and managing three competing priorities with no clear direction. Your brain's trying to protect you by planning for every scenario, but it's doing it at the worst possible time. One thing that might help: when you catch yourself in that spiral, try naming what's happening out loud or in your head: "I'm catastrophizing about the client finding bugs." Sometimes just labeling the pattern creates a tiny bit of distance from it. Then you could try this—pick one specific worry from the spiral and ask yourself: "What's one small thing I could do tomorrow to address this?" Write it down. Your mind might settle a bit if it feels like there's a plan, even a tiny one.

**Work overload with no clear priority:** The "just do your best" thing from your manager—that's frustrating because it puts all the decision-making and risk on you without giving you what you actually need, which is clarity about what matters most. When everything feels urgent and you're getting no guidance, it's hard to know where to even start. Have you been able to tell your manager directly that you need them to prioritize these three things? Like, "I can't do all three well—which one should I focus on first?" Sometimes managers don't realize they're being vague until someone pushes back with a direct question.

**Isolation and declining invites:** You're seeing the pattern—you know that avoiding friends is probably making things harder—but you're also genuinely exhausted and don't have energy to explain. That's real. One option: is there one friend you could send a simple text to? Not explaining everything, just something like "I'm in a rough work stretch, can't do hangouts right now but wanted to say hi." Sometimes just keeping one thread alive feels less overwhelming than trying to maintain everything or letting it all drop.

Which of these three feels most urgent to you right now—the sleep, the work situation, or the isolation?

exchanges.user:
So I tried the thing you said about naming the pattern. Worked better than I expected, honestly. I caught myself spiraling around 3am last night and just said out loud "okay, catastrophizing about production bugs" and it actually broke the loop for like twenty minutes. Didn't solve the sleep problem entirely but at least I wasn't lying there for two hours in full panic mode.

Work situation got worse though. I sent my manager an email asking him to prioritize the three projects and his response was basically "they're all important, use your judgment." So that was useless. I've stopped asking for clarity because it's obvious he's not going to give it. Just grinding through at this point. The deadline is in nine days now so I'm at least in the final stretch.

Been thinking about what you said on the isolation thing. You're probably right that I need to keep some thread alive with people. But honestly, I'm not sure I have the mental bandwidth to even text right now. I know that sounds dramatic. It's just like, even thinking about having to explain why I've been MIA feels exhausting. Easier to just wait until work calms down and then surface again.

How much of this is just normal stress response versus actually a problem? Like, am I overreacting here or is it reasonable that I can't sleep and don't want to talk to anyone?
exchanges.assistant:
**The naming technique:** That's a real win—you tried something new at 3am when you were in the thick of it, and it gave you twenty minutes of relief. That matters. The fact that it worked even partially tells you something: your mind *can* shift out of that loop when you give it a gentle redirect. You might keep experimenting with it. Some people add a second step after naming the pattern: "I'm catastrophizing about production bugs... and I can't solve this at 3am." Sometimes naming the pattern *and* the fact that you're powerless to fix it right now helps your brain let go a bit more.

**Manager giving you nothing:** Yeah, that response is frustrating. "Use your judgment" when you've explicitly asked for prioritization just dumps the decision-making onto you without any support. You've stopped asking, which makes sense—why keep going to a dry well? I'm curious though: have you made a call yourself on which project gets priority? Not because you *should* have to, but because in the absence of direction, picking one yourself and committing to it might reduce some of the mental load of feeling like you're failing at all three simultaneously. It's not ideal, but sometimes unilateral clarity beats ambiguous paralysis. What would happen if you just decided "Project A gets my best work, the other two get whatever's left" and let the chips fall?

**Isolation and bandwidth:** It doesn't sound dramatic—it sounds like you're running on fumes and even a "hey, been swamped, miss you" text feels like one more thing. That's real. Here's the thing though: you're asking whether this is a normal stress response or a problem, and I think that question itself is a signal. When someone's in a normal stress response, they usually don't wonder if it's too much—they just push through and bounce back after. The fact that you're questioning it, that sleep is wrecked, that the idea of a single text feels exhausting, that you're isolating—it suggests you're running past "normal stress" into something heavier. Not catastrophic, but not sustainable either.

You've got nine days until the deadline. What happens after that? Do you expect to surface and feel normal again, or is there a part of you that worries this might not lift on its own?

exchanges.user:
So the work deadline got moved up again. Now it's six days. I'm not even angry anymore, just kind of numb about it. My manager sent out this email saying "we need to accelerate the timeline to stay competitive" which is corporate speak for "we made a business decision and you all have to absorb it." Nobody asked us if that was possible. They just decided it was.

I've been sleeping maybe four hours a night, and not great sleep—more like passing out from exhaustion and then waking up at 4am with my heart racing. Tried the naming thing again a couple times but honestly it feels pointless when the actual problem is that I have too much work and not enough time. The pattern-naming works when you can actually do something about the situation, but what am I supposed to do here? Work faster? I'm already going as fast as I can.

Haven't texted anyone. You were right that it's a signal I'm not doing okay, but knowing that doesn't really change anything. I still don't have the energy or mental space to reach out. My mom called yesterday and I just let it go to voicemail. Which is unlike me. She'll probably call again and I'll have to deal with it eventually but right now I just can't face explaining to her how much of a mess everything is.

The isolation thing is starting to feel less like a choice and more like something that's just happening to me, which is maybe the part that's actually concerning. Does that make sense?
exchanges.assistant:
**The deadline moving again:** Six days now. That numbness you're describing—that's what happens when your system has been in high alert for so long that it can't sustain the anger or panic anymore. It's not that you don't care, it's that your emotional resources are depleted. And you're right: they made a business decision and handed you the consequences without asking if it was even possible. That's not in your head. That's a real thing that happened, and it's reasonable to feel stuck and powerless in response to it.

**Sleep falling apart:** Four hours of fragmented sleep, waking up at 4am with your heart racing—that's your body staying in threat mode even when you're trying to rest. The naming technique helped when the deadline was nine days out, but now that it's six and you're running on fumes, yeah, it's going to feel pointless. You're right that the technique works better when there's some actual control over the situation. Right now you don't have control over the deadline or the workload, so your nervous system is just... staying activated. One thing that might help in the moment when you wake up with your heart racing: put your hand on your chest and try slowing your exhale. Breathe in for 4 counts, out for 6. Do that for two minutes. It won't fix the work problem, but it signals to your body that you're not in immediate physical danger, which might help you get back to sleep. The goal isn't to solve everything—it's just to get your heart rate down enough to catch another hour.

**Isolation shifting from choice to something happening *to* you:** Yes, that makes complete sense, and that's the concerning part. When you said you let your mom's call go to voicemail and that's "unlike you"—that's a signal. You're not actively choosing isolation anymore because it feels easier; you're just... not able to reach out, even when you know you probably should. That shift from "I don't have energy for this" to "I can't do this even though I want to" is worth paying attention to. It suggests you're past the point where willpower or good intentions are enough.

Here's what I'm hearing across all of this: you're six days from a deadline that keeps accelerating, you're sleeping four hours a night, your body is in constant activation, you're isolating in ways that feel involuntary, and you're starting to lose access to things that usually matter to you (like responding to your mom). That's not just normal stress. That's your system under serious strain.

What happens if you don't meet the deadline? Like, actually—what's the worst realistic outcome?

exchanges.user:
I didn't meet the deadline. Well, we didn't. The whole team missed it. I turned in what I had at 11pm on Friday and basically sent a message saying "this is what's done, these are the known issues, here's what still needs work." My manager's response was to forward it to the client with some corporate language about "iterative delivery" and "addressing issues in phase two."

So the thing I was losing sleep over for weeks—the catastrophe I was running through at 3am—just... didn't happen the way I feared. The client didn't blow up. There's no emergency. We're just behind, which apparently was always the plan anyway, they just didn't tell us that until we were already panicking.

I'm still wrecked though. Slept maybe twelve hours straight on Saturday, which sounds good until you realize it's because my body just gave out. Woke up Sunday feeling like I'd been hit by a truck. My mom showed up at my apartment unannounced because I kept ignoring her calls. She looked at me and just said "you look terrible" which, fair. She stayed for like three hours and made me eat something. We didn't really talk about anything heavy, just... existed in the same space for a bit. It helped more than I expected.

The isolation thing you mentioned—yeah, it's still there. My friends texted asking if I wanted to hang out this week and I said yes because my mom kind of made me promise I'd try. But I'm not sure I actually want to see anyone. I'm just agreeing because it's what I'm supposed to do. Does that count as actually reaching out or is it just performing the thing?
exchanges.assistant:
**The deadline that wasn't a catastrophe:** So the thing you were catastrophizing about at 3am for weeks—production bugs, client blowup, everything falling apart—turned out to be... a non-event. They just moved it to "phase two" with some corporate language and everyone moved on. That gap between what your nervous system was preparing for (disaster) and what actually happened (mild inconvenience) is worth noticing. Your fear was real, your exhaustion was real, but the outcome your brain kept showing you at 3am didn't materialize. Sometimes our threat system gets louder than the actual threat. Doesn't mean you were wrong to feel it—just means your system was working overtime to protect you from something that ended up being manageable.

**Your body giving out:** Twelve hours of sleep on Saturday after weeks of four-hour nights—that's not rest, that's collapse. Your body hit a wall and just shut down. And then waking up Sunday feeling like you'd been hit by a truck makes sense: you weren't recovering, you were crash-landing. That kind of exhaustion doesn't fix itself in one weekend. You're still carrying weeks of accumulated depletion. Be gentle with the fact that you're not bouncing back instantly. You ran yourself into the ground for something that turned out to be less urgent than everyone made it seem.

**Your mom showing up:** She saw through the ignored calls, showed up, said "you look terrible," and stayed for three hours without making you explain everything. That's... actually kind of perfect. You didn't have to perform or justify or give her the full narrative—she just sat with you and made sure you ate. You said it helped more than you expected, and I believe that. Sometimes what we need isn't someone to fix it or understand it, just someone to be there while we exist. That's connection without the cost of explanation.

**Agreeing to see friends because your mom made you promise:** Is it "actually reaching out" or "performing the thing"? Honestly—does it matter? You said yes. You're showing up. The internal experience might be "I don't actually want to," but the action is still movement toward people instead of away from them. Motivation doesn't have to come first. Sometimes you do the thing and the feeling follows later, sometimes it doesn't and you just did the thing anyway. Both count. If you see your friends and it feels hollow or performative the whole time, that's data—you'll know you're not ready yet. But if you go and some small part of it feels okay, even for ten minutes, that's also data. You're testing whether connection still works for you, and that's worth doing even if you're ambivalent about it.

The fact that you're asking "does it count" suggests you're worried it's not real unless it feels authentic. What if the goal isn't authenticity right now—what if it's just not disappearing completely?

exchanges.user:
Saw my friends yesterday. It was... fine, actually. Better than fine. We went to this bar near campus that I haven't been to in months and I forgot how much I actually like being around them. One of them, Sarah, kept making these dumb jokes and I found myself laughing without having to think about it. That hasn't happened in a while. We didn't talk about work or any of the stuff I've been stressed about—they just treated me like normal and I guess that's what I needed. No explanation required.

But here's the weird part: I'm still exhausted. Like, bone-deep tired. I slept ten hours last night and woke up feeling like I could sleep another eight. Is that normal after that kind of work stretch or is something else going on? My mom says it takes time to recover from that level of burnout, but part of me wonders if I'm just... depressed now or something. I'm not sad exactly. I'm just kind of flat. Work got back to normal pace (no new apocalyptic deadlines, at least) and that should feel like relief but mostly it just feels like I'm going through the motions.

Also had this moment yesterday where I realized I never actually apologized to my mom for ignoring her calls for weeks. I should probably do that. We haven't really talked about it since she showed up and made me eat something. It's just sitting there.
exchanges.assistant:
**Seeing your friends:** That moment with Sarah—laughing without having to think about it—that's significant. You'd been so depleted that even the idea of a text felt overwhelming, and then you showed up and remembered what it's like to just exist around people who know you. No performance, no explanation, just being treated like yourself. That's what connection does when it works: it reminds you that you're still in there somewhere, even when everything else feels flat.

**The exhaustion that won't lift:** Ten hours of sleep and waking up ready for eight more—yeah, that tracks after the kind of sustained stress you just came out of. Your body was in crisis mode for weeks: four-hour nights, constant activation, running on adrenaline to meet a deadline that kept moving. Now that the threat's gone, your system is trying to pay back that debt all at once. It's not just physical tiredness—it's your nervous system finally exhaling after holding its breath for a month. Your mom's right that recovery takes time. This isn't a weekend thing; it's more like weeks of your body slowly remembering how to not be in survival mode.

As for whether it's depression or just the aftermath of burnout—hard to say cleanly, and honestly the line between them can be blurry. The flatness you're describing, the going-through-the-motions feeling even though work is back to normal pace—that could be your system still recalibrating, or it could be something settling in. One way to track it: if the flatness starts lifting in the next couple weeks as you get more rest and connection, it was probably just depletion. If it stays even as things stabilize, that's worth paying attention to. For now, don't fight the need for sleep. Your body's telling you what it needs.

**Your mom:** The apology that's just sitting there—yeah, that makes sense. She showed up, took care of you, didn't make you explain, and you never actually said "I'm sorry I disappeared on you." You could send her a text today. Doesn't have to be a whole thing: "Hey, I've been thinking about how I ignored your calls for weeks and I'm sorry. I wasn't doing great and I didn't know how to explain it. Thanks for showing up anyway." She'll probably just be glad you're talking to her again.

exchanges.user:
Yeah, so I texted my mom. Kept it short like you suggested. She responded with like five messages in a row, half of them just heart emojis, so I think we're good there. Haven't really processed it much but at least the thing that was sitting there is done.

Work's been fine this week, which is honestly kind of disorienting. No new crises, just normal project stuff. Everyone seems to have moved on from the deadline disaster like it never happened. I'm trying to do the same but it's weird being back to a regular pace when I spent so long in panic mode. It's like my brain hasn't caught up with the fact that I don't need to be in constant alert anymore.

The exhaustion thing is still there but less severe. I slept maybe eight hours last night which feels almost normal. Still kind of tired during the day though. My energy's been weird—some days I feel almost fine, other days I just want to stay in bed and not talk to anyone. It's inconsistent.

Oh, and I went to the gym for the first time in like two months. Just twenty minutes on the treadmill, nothing intense. Felt okay while I was doing it but then crashed pretty hard afterward. Like, disproportionately tired from minimal exercise. Is that a thing or am I just still wrecked from everything?
exchanges.assistant:
**Your mom:** Five messages and heart emojis—yeah, you're good there. She was probably just relieved to hear from you. And you're right that you haven't fully processed it yet, but honestly? You don't need to. You identified the thing that was sitting there, you handled it, it's done. That's enough. Sometimes closure is just tying off a loose thread, not having a big emotional reckoning about it.

**Work back to normal pace, but your brain hasn't caught up:** That disorientation makes complete sense. You spent weeks in a state where every day felt like a potential catastrophe, your nervous system was running hot, and now... nothing. No crisis. Just regular project work. But your threat system doesn't switch off instantly just because the external situation changed. It's still scanning for the next emergency, still primed to react, even though there's nothing to react to. That's why it feels weird—your environment says "you're safe now" but your body's still waiting for the other shoe to drop. It can take a few weeks for your nervous system to recalibrate and believe that the threat is actually over. You might notice yourself feeling jumpy or hypervigilant about work stuff even when it's routine. That's normal after what you just went through.

**Energy being inconsistent:** Some days almost fine, other days you want to stay in bed—that's your system still recovering. It's not linear. You're not going to wake up one day and be fully back to baseline. Recovery from that kind of sustained stress comes in waves: a good day, then a crash, then two okay days, then another crash. The crashes get less frequent and less intense over time, but they don't disappear all at once. The fact that you're sleeping eight hours now instead of four is progress, even if you're still tired during the day.

**Gym crash:** Twenty minutes on the treadmill and then crashing hard afterward—yes, that's a thing, and it doesn't mean you're doing something wrong. When your body's been running on adrenaline and stress hormones for weeks and then suddenly has to do physical exertion, it doesn't have much left in the tank. You're still in a depleted state. The exercise itself was probably fine, but your recovery capacity is still compromised. That disproportionate tiredness is your body saying "I'm still paying off the debt from the last month." It'll get better as you keep recovering, but for now, maybe pace yourself: short, gentle movement, and don't expect to bounce back instantly afterward. You're rebuilding capacity, not testing your limits.

exchanges.user:
Been a few days. Work's been genuinely fine, which is starting to feel less weird and more just... normal. I'm not waiting for the other shoe to drop as much. Still tired but it's more manageable now.

The inconsistent energy thing you mentioned—yeah, that's exactly what's happening. Had a really good day on Wednesday, felt almost like myself again, then Thursday I just crashed and stayed in bed until like 2pm. But knowing that's normal and expected somehow makes it less scary? Like at least I understand what's happening instead of thinking I'm just broken.

Tried the gym thing again today, kept it super light. Just a walk around the neighborhood instead of the treadmill. Didn't crash afterward, which was nice. I think I'm starting to get the idea that pushing hard isn't the answer right now.

Quick thing though—I've been noticing something that's been nagging at me. The sleep thing got better once the deadline passed, which makes sense. But before that, even when I was sleeping four hours a night and panicking, I never once considered that maybe I should actually talk to someone about it. Like, professionally. I just kept trying to manage it myself with whatever you suggested. Which some of it helped, but also... I didn't even think to ask if I needed actual help. Is that a normal thing people do or is that weird? Like, should I have recognized earlier that I was past the point where self-help stuff was enough?
exchanges.assistant:
**Work feeling normal again:** That shift from "waiting for the other shoe to drop" to just... existing at a normal pace—that's your nervous system starting to believe the threat is actually over. It doesn't happen all at once, but the fact that you're noticing it means the recalibration is happening. You're not forcing yourself to feel safe, you're just starting to actually feel it.

**The crash pattern making more sense:** Yeah, exactly—Wednesday felt almost like yourself, Thursday you stayed in bed until 2pm. That's the wave pattern of recovery. And you're right that knowing it's normal makes it less scary. When you don't have a framework for what's happening, the crashes feel like evidence that something's fundamentally wrong with you. But when you can see it as "my system is still recovering and this is what that looks like," it's just data, not a crisis. The crashes will keep getting less frequent.

**Lighter movement working better:** A walk around the neighborhood instead of the treadmill, no crash afterward—that's you learning to pace yourself. You're figuring out what your actual capacity is right now instead of pushing to where you think it should be. That's a skill, and it's one that'll serve you outside of just exercise.

**Not considering professional help earlier:** This is a really good question, and I'm glad you're asking it. So—first, no, it's not weird that you didn't think to seek professional help while you were in the thick of it. When you're in crisis mode, your brain narrows focus to immediate survival: get through the next day, the next deadline, the next sleepless night. You're not thinking "should I be in therapy?"—you're thinking "how do I make it to Friday?" That tunnel vision is a feature of stress, not a personal failing.

But here's the thing: the fact that you're asking now, after the crisis passed, whether you should have recognized it earlier—that suggests you're wondering if there's a pattern here. Like, will you recognize it next time? Or will you end up in the same place again, grinding yourself down before you realize you need more support than you can give yourself?

There's no clean answer to "when is self-help enough and when do you need professional support," but here are some signals that might help you recognize it earlier if this happens again:

- **Sleep disruption lasting more than a week or two** (you were at weeks of 4-hour nights)
- **Isolation starting to feel involuntary** (you named that shift—"not a choice anymore, something happening to me")
- **Physical symptoms that don't match the situation** (heart racing at 4am, disproportionate exhaustion)
- **Losing access to things that usually matter** (ignoring your mom's calls when that's "unlike you")

Any one of those alone might just be stress. But when you've got three or four at once and they're not improving, that's usually a sign that the situation is outpacing your ability to manage it on your own.

None of this means you failed by not seeking help earlier. You were doing what you could with what you had. But if you're asking because you want to be better at recognizing when you're past that threshold next time—yeah, those signals above are worth keeping in the back of your mind. And honestly? If you're still feeling flat or exhausted in another few weeks even as things stay stable, that might be worth exploring with someone. Not because something's broken, just because sometimes talking to a professional helps you process the aftermath in ways that self-help can't quite reach.

Does that land, or does it feel like I'm missing part of what you were asking?

exchanges.user:
Been thinking about what you said about recognizing the signals earlier. The sleep thing, the isolation, all of it. I guess I'm wondering if there's something about how I'm wired that makes me just... power through until I break, you know? Like, is that a personality thing or learned behavior or what.

Anyway, that's not why I'm reaching out today. Something else came up. I've been back at work for a bit now and things are genuinely fine, but I noticed this pattern where I'm catastrophizing about future deadlines even though nothing's actually happened. Like, we'll get assigned a new project and my first thought is "okay, when is this going to explode in my face?" I'm not sleeping badly or anything, but there's this constant low-level anxiety about work that I didn't have before all this happened. It's like my nervous system learned that work = threat and now it won't turn that off.

Which brings me back to the question about whether I should talk to someone professionally. Not because I'm in crisis or anything, but because I feel like maybe I need help understanding why I jump straight to catastrophe mode and how to actually change that pattern instead of just managing it when it happens. Does that make sense? Or am I overthinking this?
exchanges.assistant:
**The "power through until you break" pattern:** Yeah, that's worth looking at. Is it personality or learned behavior? Probably both, and they reinforce each other. Some people are temperamentally more inclined to push through discomfort—high tolerance for stress, strong work ethic, maybe a bit of "I can handle this myself" wiring. But that gets shaped by what you learn works: if powering through has gotten you results in the past (good grades, promotions, respect), your brain files that under "successful strategy" and keeps using it. The problem is it works... until it doesn't. And by the time you hit the breaking point, you've already been ignoring signals for weeks. The pattern isn't a flaw in you—it's a strategy that worked in some contexts and then overstayed its welcome. Recognizing it now means you can start building a different relationship with those early signals instead of waiting for collapse to tell you something was wrong.

**Catastrophizing about future deadlines even though nothing's actually happened:** This makes complete sense. You spent weeks in a state where work genuinely *was* a threat—deadlines moved without warning, your manager gave you no support, your nervous system was in constant activation. That wasn't irrational; that was your system accurately responding to an unpredictable, high-stakes situation. But now that the external threat is gone, your nervous system hasn't fully updated its threat assessment. It learned "work = danger" and it's still running that program even though the current situation is stable. That constant low-level anxiety you're describing—"when is this going to explode in my face?"—is your system trying to protect you by staying vigilant. It's not that you're broken; it's that your threat system is still online, scanning for the next crisis, because last time it let its guard down, a deadline moved up by two weeks with no warning.

One thing that might help: when you notice that catastrophizing thought ("when is this going to explode?"), try asking yourself: "What's different about this project compared to the last one?" Look for actual evidence—do you have a reasonable timeline? Is your manager communicating clearly? Are there early warning signs, or is this just your system assuming the worst because of what happened before? Sometimes naming the difference between "then" and "now" helps your nervous system start to re-learn that not every project is the deadline disaster. It won't happen overnight, but over time, if projects keep *not* exploding, your system will start to recalibrate. Right now it's just protecting you based on the most recent data it has, which was "work became a crisis with no warning."

**Whether to talk to someone professionally:** You're asking a really clear question: not "am I in crisis?" but "do I need help understanding why I jump straight to catastrophe mode and how to actually change that pattern instead of just managing it when it happens?" That's... a great reason to talk to someone. You're not looking for crisis intervention; you're looking for insight into your patterns and tools to shift them at the root level, not just band-aid them when they flare up. That's exactly what therapy is good for—especially something like CBT (which looks at thought patterns and how to restructure them) or ACT (which works on your relationship with anxious thoughts so they have less power over you).

You're not overthinking this. You're asking whether you want to keep white-knuckling through the low-level anxiety and catastrophizing on your own, or whether you want help building a different relationship with it. If you're already noticing the pattern, wondering if it's something deeper about how you're wired, and asking "how do I actually change this?"—that's a pretty clear signal that you're ready for more than just self-management. It doesn't mean you failed at handling it yourself. It means you're recognizing the limits of what you can shift on your own and you're open to getting support for the deeper work.

If you do decide to reach out, look for someone who does CBT or ACT—both are evidence-based for anxiety and catastrophic thinking. You could also try a few sessions and see if it feels useful. Therapy isn't a lifetime commitment; it's a tool you use when it's helpful. And honestly? The fact that you're asking this question now, when you're stable and not in crisis, is the ideal time to start. You've got bandwidth to actually engage with the work instead of just trying to survive.

Does it feel like the right move, or are you still on the fence?

exchanges.user:
So I actually did something. Started looking for therapists this week—found a few who do CBT and have openings. I'm meeting with someone next Tuesday. Part of me feels kind of relieved about it, but another part feels like I'm admitting defeat or something. Like, shouldn't I be able to figure this out on my own at this point? I know that's probably the exact pattern you were talking about, so I'm not going to spiral on it. Just noticing it.

Work's been fine. No new catastrophes. But I did catch myself spiraling about a client deliverable that's due in three weeks and I tried what you suggested—asking myself what's actually different about this project. And honestly? There's nothing alarming. Timeline's reasonable, my manager's been clear about expectations, no moving goalposts. So intellectually I know this isn't the deadline disaster situation. But I still felt that spike of anxiety when I thought about it. Knowing the thought isn't rational didn't actually make it go away, which is frustrating.

Also been sleeping better, which is good. Eight hours most nights. Energy's more consistent now too. I'm not crashing on random days like I was a few weeks ago. So physically I'm feeling more like myself again.
